data.title: Theatre News: Cast Albums, Queen of the Mist, Kimberly Akimbo and The Oyster Radio Hour
data.meta_description: The new Broadway cast recordings for The Great Gatsby, The Outsiders and Suffs are out. However Here We Are, the final Original Cast Recording from legendary…
data.text:
The new Broadway cast recordings for The Great Gatsby, The Outsiders and Suffs are out. However Here We Are, the final Original Cast Recording from legendary composer Stephen Sondheim and Jason Robert Brown’s The Connector are out on YouTube and these are the best scores of the year.

Another CD out is My Favorite Things: The Rodgers & Hammerstein 80th Anniversary Concert: featuring a 40-piece orchestra and stars, including Michael Ball, Maria Friedman, Daniel Dae Kim, Audra McDonald, Aaron Tveit, and Patrick Wilson, the Concert was recorded live at London’s Theatre Royal Drury Lane. The celebration showcases original arrangements of Rodgers & Hammerstein’s iconic songs from Oklahoma!, South Pacific, Cinderella, The Sound of Music and more.

Mary Testa return to Queen of the Mist in New Jersey Concert Performances at New Jersey’s Montclair State University. The concert performances of Michael John LaChiusa’s Queen of the Mist featuring the work’s original star, Broadway favorite Mary Testa.

Adam Gwon and Sarah Hammond’s Richard Rodgers Award-winning musical String has joined BroadwayLicensing Global’s catalogue and is now available for professional and non-professional productions. The company also dropped a studio cast recording of the show July 16, which is now available on Spotify, Apple Music, and all digital platforms.

Three-Time Tony Nominee Carolee Carmello to Star in Kimberly Akimbo National Tour” by Broadway.com’s Darryn King – “Three-time Tony nominee Carolee Carmello will play Kimberly in the national tour of Kimberly Akimbo.

Little Island is bringing Tony Award® nominees Amber Gray (Hadestown) and Amber Iman (Lempicka) to perform in The Oyster Radio Hour, which begins performances on Wednesday, July 31 and will run through Sunday, August 4 as part of Little Island’s blockbuster summer season.

The Oyster Radio Hour is a live, three-act family-friendly radio show combining science, story and song that celebrates the resilience of oysters and their crucial ecological roles. Beginning at 8PM each evening, the show blends hope and interconnectedness, spotlighting the humble oyster’s journey of revival, including special Broadway guests Amber Gray and Amber Iman.

During The Oyster Radio Hour’s run in the Amph through August 4, the Island’s central plaza, known as the Play Ground, will transform from 6:30-10PM daily into a one-of-a-kind Oyster Market, with food and beverages curated and overseen by New Amsterdam Market founder and world-famous market designer Robert LaValva.

Alongside live oyster shucking, the market will feature 10 local vendors selling their unique culinary creations, which pair perfectly with the live performance. The local vendors include Real Mothershuckers, Oyster Party, Lobster Place, Houseman, Dayboat Blue, Cervo’s, Té Company, La Newyorkina, Chomps Elysées, and Pamina Dolce Gelato. Danny Childs, author of Slow Drinks, will make summer bespoke cocktails during a bar takeover on Friday, August 3.

The Oyster Radio Hour is a collaboration between RR Sigel, who was the Associate Artistic Director of NY PopsUp in 2021; WNYC podcast producer Ana González, previously of Radiolab: For Kids; composer Angélica Negrón who has performed at Opera Philadelphia, the LA Philharmonic, NY Philharmonic, Seattle Symphony, Dallas Symphony Orchestra, and more; and Emmy® and Drama Desk Award®-nominated songwriter Mark Sonnenblick.

Keenan Tyler Oliphant (Hadestown) serves as director with Miller & Harlow as writers; Jeanette Oi-Suk Yew (Kimberly Akimbo) as lighting/video designer; Beth Lake(Camelot) as sound designer; Dr. Matthew Hare, Elliott Ma, Ayasha Guerin, Moody Harney, and Alan Michelson as audio interviewees; and Beatrice Perez-Arche as stage manager.

Little Island’s first annual, four-month-long summer season of world premieres, which kicked off on June 1, features a total of nine newly commissioned pieces. Little Island’s new arts program moves towards the future with a commitment to a multi-year roster of original work, all commissioned by and developed at Little Island. Bookended by the premiere of choreographer Twyla Tharp’s newest work How Long Blues and a 90-minute remix of Mozart’s The Marriage of Figaro in which outré opera diva Anthony Roth Costanzo sings every leading role, the season offers premieres of varying scales across all areas of performance – including music, dance, theater, opera, comedy, jazz, pop, and funk, all outdoors and directly sited on the Hudson River at 14th Street in New York City. The Amph, the park’s 700-seat amphitheater, will house larger scale performances at a $25 ticket price, while The Glade, the park’s

Moving from New York City Center Encores! to Broadway, Once Upon a Mattress at The Hudson Theatre still is appealable, bouncy and has heart. This shimmering revival had the perfect opening (night) for a princess! Helmed by Tony-nominated Encores! Artistic Director Lear deBessonet (Into the Woods, Lionel Bart’s Oliver!), with a new adaptation by Amy Sherman-Palladino (The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel), this production is sure to please. Marshall Barer, Jay Thompson, and Dean Fuller’s book has been transformed and is much more palatable to today’s audience’s thanks to Ms. Palladino rewrite.

Sutton Foster makes this role her very own. This is not an easy task, as it made the young Carol Burnett a break out star. She is hilarious, as are her inserted one-liners. Her voice is not as strong as it should be, but she is winning and her chemistry with Michael Urie is infectious.

There has been major cast changes from Encore. The show opens with the Jester/ Minstrel (Daniel Breaker) singing about how we don’t quite know the fairy tale of old. He brings us back to where it all took place, a mythical kingdom in a desperate search for a suitable princess for the clueless Prince Dauntless (the adorable Michael Urie ). Queen Aggravain (Ana Gasteyer replaces the deliciously sinister Harriet Harris), is determined that no one is good enough for her son. However, no one can marry until Dauntless does.

This is a problem for Lady Larken (a glorious voiced Nikki Renée Daniels), as she is pregnant by the stupid Sir Harry (Will Chase replaces the uber handsome Cheyenne Jackson), so Harry goes in search of a princess and brings back Winifred, Fred for short (Sutton Foster). Anxious for a mate she swims past the moat, over the castle walls, singing the hit song “Shy.”

Dauntless and Fred immediately have a connection, which makes the Queen and her lackey The Wizard (the delightfully quirky Brooks Ashmanskas who took over for Francis Jue) come up with a sensitivity test of a pea under 20 mattresses to sabotage the union. The mute King Sextimus (the fabulous David Patrick Kelly ) along with the rest of the kingdom find out the plan and load the mattresses with more than just a pea and the Kingdom is finally set right.

Urie gives us a riotous version of a man/child dominated but with heart and soul, so you root for him to win his princess.

Daniel Breaker does a winning “Very Soft Shoes”

Lear deBessonet’s love of this piece shows in her direction as she brinsg the audience along on this journey.

The choreography by Lorin Latarro, is seriously fun especially “Spanish Panic” and “Song of Love”.

My biggest complaint is when Encore’s moves to Broadway, they put the orchestra on stage. What wowed me at Encores, was upsetting here. When the orchestra played the opening strains a smile started to spread all over the audiences face and stayed there for more than 2½ hours, because it was an old fashion musical done well. The music by the late Mary Rodgers (daughter of Richard), with lyrics by Marshall Barer came alive at encores, here because of the placement the music side falls flat, as we learn the true story of “The Princess and the Pea.”

The music direction by Mary-Mitchell Campbell, scenic design by David Zinn, costumes by Andrea Hood, lighting design by Amith Chandrashaker, sound design by Kai Harada, hair and wig design by J. Jared Janas, and physical comedy and effects by Skylar Fox. Kimberlee Wertz is the music coordinator, orchestrations by Hershy Kay, Arthur Beck, and Carrol Huxley needed an oomph in coming to Broadway.

For this production think fractured fairy tales, starring the comedically talented Sutton Foster as Winnifred the Woebegone otherwise known as Fred.

It is always brings tears to my eyes and a joy to my heart to see musical theatre history brought back.

Once Upon a Mattress: Hudson Theatre, 141 W 44th Street, through November 30th.

MR. DAREDEVIL — (Via Deadline) Wow. This isn’t your Netflix’s Daredevil. Visceral, cinematic, bloody — this is a Daredevil in the way that James Bond got a reboot with Daniel Craig.

The first look at the series was revealed Friday for the crowd at D23 in Anaheim. And there’s a big homage to Heat with Charlie Cox’s Matt Murdock and Vincent Donofiro’s Kingpin meeting in a diner to verbally draw their boundaries.

“If you step out of line, I’m going to be there,” says Murdock.

Kingpin, laughing, wonders if it’s Daredevil talking or Murdock.

In another shot, a prison inmate tells Murdock, “You don’t understand, people needed you.”

Also seen here is Jon Bernthal’s Frank Castle aka The Punisher, a long-haired ruffian who comes up against Murdock in fisticuffs before the former realizes it’s his ally.

The tagline that runs in the trailer: “The Devil’s Work Is Never Done.”

Marvel President Kevin Feige also confirmed a season 2 will be shooting soon.

Daredevil: Born Again follows original star Charlie Cox as Matt Murdock, a blind attorney-turned-crimefighting superhero, and also features Vincent D’Onofrio reprising his role as mob boss Wilson Fisk aka Kingpin and Jon Bernthal returning as Punisher.

The cast of Daredevil: Born Again also includes Margarita Levieva, Arty Froushan, Sandrine Holt, Michael Gandolfini and Nikki M. James.

We gotta wait till March 1, 2025 for Daredevil: Born Again.

I got to admit, it’s great to have the original Netflix-band back together, but somehow the trailer didn’t work for me. It looked somehow different. Take a look:

SNL AT 50 — Hard to believe but Saturday Night Live enters its 50th year in September. Save for a year, Lorne Michaels has been the conductor of the train the entire time. I’ve watch it since that first show, so I’m able to comment somewhat authoritatively on the trailer for the movie Saturday Night coming in October 11.

It looks pretty good. I know Jason Reitman is onboard, so it’ll be pretty much right-on. Take a look at the trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iZ9O_tl5Npk

and what the Daily Mail said: https://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-13727345/Saturday-Night-Live-movie-LOOK-Trailer-SNL-episode.html

SHORT TAKES — Micky Dolenz was at Mark Lapidos’ The Fest For Beatles Fans this weekend and is seen here with Billy J. Kramer. He also sang “Rocky Raccoon,” “Oh Darling” and “Johnny B Goode” backed by the Liverpool Band with Lawrence Juber from Wings joining in.

Our spy there said Dolenz took the SRO crowd back to the 60’s in fine fashion …. Playboy Magazine is issuing its first print-issue in decades. Read all about it: https://avn.com/business/articles/novelty/playboy-announces-return-to-print-revival-of-playmates-bunnies-934470.html?fbclid=IwY2xjawEkRPVleHRuA2FlbQIxMQABHQmnmG_FGc4hE8R6Kz_Q7GxZg-qHXUfHnel8rYqmtyoIvAWAIiA9dONdzQ_aem_M0kPD-EPqKmP3UFQgj-uK

For my money, Lanie Speiser should have been the new editor … Niki was tremendous on the CBS Saturday Sessions … Sad Deadline item about a forthcoming Gary Coleman documentary: uKAhttps://deadline.com/2024/08/gary-coleman-documentary-peacock-trailer-1236034809/

… CBS weather-guru John Elliot coined a new phrase I had never heard for last week’s epic rain-bursts: training rain …

Is the world ready for a live-Chicago recording froim 1971? Bring it on. Consistently one of the best groups around. Read about it here: https://theseconddisc.com/2024/08/06/chicago-kennedy-center-1971-cd-vinyl/ … Happy BDay Cori Gardner!

NAMES IN THE NEWS — Markos Papdatos; Lush Ice; Tyrone Bijan; Anthony Pomes; Frank Zappa; Joe Banadonna; Ray Sharkey; Mary Huhn; Don Kaplan; Michael Starr; Richard Johnson; AJ Benza; Elizabeth Stanton; Joel Diamond; Gloria Gaynor; Stan Lynch; Thomas Silverman; Steve Plotnicki; Manny Bella; Don Peppe; Alan Rothstein; Marl Alpert; Tom & Lisa Cuddy; Greg D’Alessandro and ZIGGY!

Images on this page have been licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license.

Did you know Bonnie & Clyde: The Musical was filmed live and can be streamed online On Demand? Filmed live at Theatre Royal Drury Lane during two special one-off concert stagings in January 2022, Bonnie & Clyde: The Musical stars Tony Award-nominee Jeremy Jordan as Clyde – reprising the role he originated in the Broadway premiere in 2011 – and Olivier Award-nominee Frances Mayli McCann as Bonnie, who went on to originate the role of Bonnie in the West End premiere run. The filmed concert staging also features George Maguire as Buck, Natalie McQueen as Blanche, Trevor Dion Nicholas as Preacher, Liam Tamne as Ted, Casey Al-Shaqsy as Stella, Simon Anthony as Cop/Bud/Archie/Deputy Johnson, Gillian Bevan as Cummie Barrow/Eleanor, Eloise Davies as Trish, Adrian Grove as Henry Barrow, Debbie Kurup as Governor Miriam Ferguson, Matthew Malthouse as Bob Alcorn, Jeremy Secomb as Judge/Sheriff Schmid, Russell Wilcox as Captain Frank Hamer, and Julie Yammanee as Emma Parker.

The two sold-out concerts in London were directed by Nick Winston. The fabulous score has music by multi-Grammy®, Tony® and Emmy® Award nominee Frank Wildhorn (Jekyll & Hyde, The Scarlett Pimpernell, Death Note), lyrics by Tony® and Oscar® winner Don Black (Sunset Boulevard, Aspects of Love), a book by Emmy® Award nominee Ivan Menchell (Blended [movie], The Cemetery Club, Death Note The Musical). Wildhorn, and Black were Tony-nominated for their score.

“Disney’s Snow White” a live action musical reimagining of the classic 1937 film just released their trailer. The magical music adventure journeys back to the timeless story with beloved characters Bashful, Doc, Dopey, Grumpy, Happy, Sleepy, and Sneezy. “Disney’s Snow White” is directed by Marc Webb and produced by Marc Platt and Jared LeBoff, with Callum McDougall serving as executive producer, and features all-new original songs from Benj Pasek and Justin Paul. Rachel Zegler and Gal Gadot star.

Speaking of Pasek and Paul, Hugh Jackman‘s passion project “The Greatest Showman” is finally getting a live stage show, thanks to Disney. At D23 in Anaheim on Friday, Disney showcased a medley of upcoming musical theater shows including dates for Frozen and Hercules that will debut on the West End. After a collection of rousing performances from the Lion King and Beauty and the Beast, to name, what was heard was “Ladies and gents, this is the moment you’ve waited for.” The crowd was then surprised with a rendition of “The Greatest Show,” from “The Greatest Showman.” Ryan Vasquez, who starred in The Notebook on Broadway, was dressed as Jackman’s character P. T. Barnum and accompanied four other cast members on stage under the signage “The Greatest Showman: The New Musical.” D23 host Yvette Nicole Brown said that the project was currently in development for a stage musical adaptation. The timing and the location have not been disclosed.

Also look for

Wicked: Release schedule for November 22, 2024 (Part 1); November 26, 2025 (Part 2) Starring Cynthia Erivo, Ariana Grande, Jonathan Bailey, Marissa Bode, Peter Dinklage, Jeff Goldblum, Ethan Slater and Michelle Yeoh.

Kiss Of The Spider Woman: Director: Bill Condon, starring Jennifer Lopez, Diego Luna and Tonatiuh. This is a film adaptation of John Kander, Fred Ebb, and Terrence McNally’s Tony Award-winning musical, based on the novel by Manuel Puig

Girl From The North Country: Screenplay and director Conor McPherson, starring Olivia Colman, Chlöe Bailey, Tosin Cole and Woody Harrelson.

Gypsy: New Regency. Director: Amy Sherman-Palladino

Joseph And The Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat: Amazon Studios, The Really Useful Group, Scott Sanders Productions. Screenplay: Daniel Goldfarb. Director: Jon M. Chu

Merrily We Roll Along: Blumhouse. Screenplay: Richard Linklater and Jonathan Marc Sherman. Director: Richard Linklater, starring Beanie Feldstein, Paul Mescal, Ben Platt, and Mallory Bechtel. A film adaptation of the George Furth-Stephen Sondheim musical, filmed over 20 years to recreate the amount of time the show covers.

On Your Feet: Sony Pictures. Screenplay and director Lissette Feliciano

Oliver!: Walt Disney Studios, Cube Vision, Marc Platt Productions. Screenplay: Danny Strong. Director: Thomas Kail, starring Ice Cube.
